repnme.cdata!:
Madagascar - Financial Sector and Private
            Enterprise Development (APEX) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated
            satisfactory, sustainability is likely, and institutional
            development impacts are substantial. Key lessons suggest
            that based on the changing process the country was
            undergoing, the appraisal team correctly understood, and
            built flexibility into the project design. Interestingly,
            the reform agenda provided the framework for a sustained
            dialogue, which benefited from the project design
            flexibility, allowing adjustments, particularly for the
            financial sector reform, and, for bank privatization,
            adjusting interest rate mechanisms, and eligibility criteria
            under the line of credit. Moreover, the financial sector,
            and reform agendas succeeded because of strong commitments
            to reform by the Government, and the Central Bank, and,
            because the Central Bank understood the importance to
            introduce changes in monetary policy, to create competencies
            capable of implementing such changes, as well as halting the
            deterioration of the financial sector, through interventions
            in two state-owned banks. The problems posed by weak
            performances of state-owned banks during the 80s and early
            90s, were correctly understood by the Government, and by the
            technical staff of the banks under privatization, who
            enabled reforms based on a technically solid approach,
            supported by key stakeholders, while, the divestiture
            process succeeded because of such technical input, and of
            adequate allocation of redundant staff.

repnme.cdata!:
Madagascar - Financial Sector and Private
            Enterprise Development (APEX) Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The rationale for IDA's involvement
            in this project is to help maintain the momentum of the
            reform process in the financial sector. The credit will
            allow more private sector initiatives not only in the
            financial sector but in the industrial and other productive
            sectors. The principal project objectives are : 1) support
            of SMEs through technical assistance and support of the
            government's ongoing restructuring efforts of the
            economy; 2) improving financial sector efficiency through
            resource mobilization, improved allocation, and interest
            rate liberalization; 3) strengthening institutions operating
            in the financial and SME support sector; 4) generating new
            employment opportunities. The project is comprised of the
            following components : 1) investment of US$45 million to
            finance projects in productive sectors promoted by private
            enterprises; 2) technical assistance to support SME
            development, staff training, strengthening of Central Bank
            supervision and monetary management capacities; and 3)
            establishment of policy conditions concerning the financial sector.

Madagascar - Financial Sector and Private
